title: California National Parks
text: I have visited 8 out of the 9 national parks in California.

title: California National Parks
text:
Redwood National and State Parks





One of my favorite national parks! The redwoods, misty trails, rivers, and even just driving on the roads in the forest can’t be beat.

title: California National Parks
text:
Lassen Volcanic National Park





I took a solo day trip to Lassen and completed a wonderful hike that I finished just in time to beat a thunderstorm.

title: California National Parks
text:
Yosemite National Park





A yearly tradition. I keep coming back to Yosemite for all that it has to offer. Sometimes I bring my dogs and stick to the paved trails, and it is always worth it.

title: California National Parks
text:
Kings Canyon National Park





I visited in the winter, and did an early morning hike that had gorgeous views of fog rolling in below.

title: California National Parks
text:
Sequoia National Park





I had a fun little snow hike with one of my friends. We were amazed at how gorgeous the tall sequoias were in the snow.

title: California National Parks
text:
Pinnacles National Park





Exploring the caves was a blast, and I was lucky enough to spot California condors soaring overhead.

title: California National Parks
text:
Channel Islands National Park





I saw a lot of Channel Island foxes! I would love to go back and camp there eventually.

title: California National Parks
text:
Joshua Tree National Park





Every year I have attended UCSB, my friends and I have taken a trip to Joshua Tree. I have camped under the stars, and it is one of my favorite places to rock climb and hike.
Still on the list: Death Valley National Park!

title: Linnea Lauffer
text:
My name is Linnea Lauffer! I am a third-year undergraduate student at UCSB, majoring in Hydrologic Sciences and Policy, and I am expected to graduate in Spring 2026.

title: Projects
text:
This project investigates how total sleep hours vary between work nights and non-work nights. Since I work a job that has primarily overnight shifts, I wanted to explore how my sleep patterns differ on nights I work compared to my days off. The data was cleaned and visualized using ‘ggplot2’ in R to compare average sleep duration and their distributions.



# Read in Packages
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)

# Read in and store data as an object
my_data <- read_csv("data/PersonalData.csv")

# Clean data
my_data_clean <- my_data |> 
  clean_names()

# Create a boxplot comparing total sleep by work night
ggplot(data = my_data_clean, # starting data frame
       aes(x = work_night, # x-axis: categorical predictor variable
       y = total_sleep_hours)) + # y-axis: continuous response variable 
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs( x = "Work Night", y = "Total Sleep (hours)") + # relabel x and y axis
  theme_minimal() # apply a clean minimalistic theme

title: Projects
text:
This project investigates how total sleep hours vary between work nights and non-work nights. Since I work a job that has primarily overnight shifts, I wanted to explore how my sleep patterns differ on nights I work compared to my days off. The data was cleaned and visualized using ‘ggplot2’ in R to compare average sleep duration and their distributions.



# Read in Packages
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)

# Read in and store data as an object
my_data <- read_csv("data/PersonalData.csv")

# Clean data
my_data_clean <- my_data |> 
  clean_names()

# Create a boxplot comparing total sleep by work night
ggplot(data = my_data_clean, # starting data frame
       aes(x = work_night, # x-axis: categorical predictor variable
       y = total_sleep_hours)) + # y-axis: continuous response variable 
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs( x = "Work Night", y = "Total Sleep (hours)") + # relabel x and y axis
  theme_minimal() # apply a clean minimalistic theme

title: Projects
section: Glacial Retreat in the Chugach Range, Alaska (1986-2010)
text:
Glacial Retreat in the Chugach Range, Alaska (1986-2010)
This project analyzed the retreat of four glaciers using Landsat satellite imagery from 1986, 2002, and 2010. The focus was on two tidewater glaciers (Columbia and Shoup), and two land-terminating glaciers (Matanuska and Nelchina). The analysis revealed that tidewater glaciers retreat more rapidly, likely due to their direct interaction with ocean water, while land-terminating glaciers are more influenced by atmospheric factors.

Methods
This project analyzed glacial retreat in the Chugach Range, Alaska, from 1986 to 2010 using Landsat images for four glaciers, two tidewater and two land-terminating. Glacial extents were manually digitized as polygons in QGIS for each time point. Geoprocessing tools identified areas of ice loss and gain, which were ten visualized spatially and quantified.
The analysis used the WGS 84 / UTM Zone 6N projection to ensure accurate area measurements. While clear retreat patterns emerged, manual digitizing and the limitations of satellite imagery (capturing only surface area) introduce some uncertainty.


Map of Glacial Retreat



Satellite Image Comparison



  1986
  2010



  
  





Interpretation
The two satellite images above, sourced from Google Earth Pro, reveal a significant decrease in glacial coverage between 1986 and 2010. This clear retreat highlights the ongoing impact of environmental changes on the glaciers in the Chugach Range.

title: About Me
text: I love my pets. I have one cat named Tioga, and two lovable Bernese Mountain Dogs, Roxy and Honor.

title: About Me
text: I love my pets. I have one cat named Tioga, and two lovable Bernese Mountain Dogs, Roxy and Honor.

title: About Me
text:
Camping & Backpacking







I love spending time outdoors, and try to get out camping whenever I can. Roxy has even joined me on a backpacking trip, and both dogs are always up for a camping adventure.

title: About Me
text:
Ocean







I have always been drawn to the water, whether it is the ocean, a lake, or a river. My friends joke that I am basically a fish and honestly, they are not wrong. **test
